sp.l: How did my Husband win thee?

sp.speaker: Torm.
sp.l: By meere force; a Bawd betray'd me to him.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Torm.
sp.l: If euer I haue wrong'd your royall bed
In act, in thought, nayle me for euer fast,
To scape this Tyger of the Kings fierce lust
I will doe any thing, I will speake treason
Or Drinke a Cup of poyson, which may blast
My inticing face, and make it leprous foule:
Ruine you all this, so you keepe vp my Soule;
That's all the wealth I care for.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I haue now no hart left to kill thee, rise, thou and I
Will like two quarrelling Gallants faster tye
A knot of Loue, we both i'th Field being wounded
Since we must needs be sharers, vse me kindly
And play not the right Citizen, to vndoe
Your partner, who 'ith stocke has more than you.
sp.stage: A noyse within. Enter the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Must you be closetted?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What are you doing?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Not getting Children.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Naked kniues; for what,
Speake, s'death speake you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: They both fell from her side.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You lie, away.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Must you be closetted?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: When hart break'st thou, thou dost too much swell,
This Aspish biting, is incurable.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be true to me I charge you, did the Queene
Offer no violence to you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: None at all.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why were these drawne,

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Know not; what's heere,
Why is this rose deni'd with a pearled teare.
When the sunneshines so warme, you know not that too,
The lambe has am'd the Lyon, the vulture tyers
Vpon the Eagles hart, these subtill wyers
Chanie Ioue, these balls, from whose flames Cupid drew,
His wild fire burnes heere, this you know not too.
I loue you, that you know not neither, y'are coy,
And proud, and faire, you know this,

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: I beseech you
Let me shake off the golden fetters you tye
About my body, you inioy a body
Without a soule, for I am now not heere.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where then.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: At home in my poore husbands armes,
This is your Court, that mine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your husbands armes,
Thou art his whore, he plai'd the theefe and rob'd
Another of thee, and to spoyle the spoyler,
Is Kingly iustice, 'tis a lawfull prize
That's ta'ne from Pirates; there's are fellow wiues.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Which of your subiects (which abroad adore
Your state, your greatnesse, presence and your throne
Of sunne beames) thinke you now are with a wanton,
Or working a chast wife to become one.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I worke thee not to be so, for when time
Shall iog his glasse and make those sands lye low
Which now are at the top, thy selfe shalt grow
In selfe same place my Queene does.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: What tree euer stood
Long and deepe rooted, that was set in blood;
I will not be your whore to weare your Crowne.
Nor call any King my Husband, but mine owne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No!

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: No 'twere shame 'mongst all our City Dames
If one could not scape free, their blasted fames.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The sound of Bels and Timbrels make you mad
As it does a Tyger, the softer that I stroke you
The worse you bite, your father and your Husband
Are at my sending come to Court, Ile lay
Honours on both their backs, here they shall stay
Because Ile keepe you here, if you doe frowne
The engine which reares vp, shall plucke all downe.
Ile fetch 'em to you my selfe.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Oh who can stifling scape in baser throngs,
When Princes Courts threaten the selfe-same wrongs!

sp.stage: Flourish. Enter King, Maleuento, Cordolente, Iago, Alphonso, Gazetto, and Tormiella.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Y'aue the best welcome which the Court can yeeld,
For the King giues it you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Your Grace is gracious.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is this your Father?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: My proper flesh and bloud Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And that your Husband?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Not I sir; I married an honest wench that went in a cap, no whim whams; I did but shuffle the first dealing, you cut last, and dealt last, by the same token you turn'd vp a Court Card.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is the man iealous!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No, but a little troubled with the yellow Iaundize, and you know if it get to the Crowne of the head, a man's gon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We send not for you hither to be brau'd,
Sirrah cast your darts elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Amongst the wild Irish Sir hereafter.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis our Queenes pleasure that your wife be call'd
Her woman, and because she will not loose her,
She hath importun'd vs to raise you both;
Your name sir?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Mine, Andrada Maleuento.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Andrada Maleuento we make you
Vice-Admirall of our Nauy.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Oh spitefull Comedy, he's not a Courtier of halfe an houres standing, and he's made a Vice already.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We make thy Husband—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: A Cuckold doe you not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Sonne you forget your selfe.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Meddle with your owne office; there's one will looke that none meddles with mine.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Is not a change good?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Yes, of a louzie shirt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take hence that fellow, he's mad.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I am indeed horne-mad, oh me, in the holyest place of the Kingdome haue I caught my vndoing, the Church gaue mee my bane.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: What the Church gaue thee, thou hast still.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Halfe parts, I thought one had tane thee vp.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Take me home with thee, Ile not stay here.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Let me not come to Court.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The King is vext, let me perswade thee Sonne
To wincke at small faults.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What sir Pandarus!

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Sends the King you to blush in's roome.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Y'are a baggage.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Goe tell the lunatique so; Andrada harke,

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: The King sir bids me sing into your eare,
Sweet notes of place and office which shall fall—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Into my mouth, I gape for 'em.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: He bids me aske what will content you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing, why Sir the powers aboue cannot please vs, and can Kings thinke you, when we are brought forth to the world, we cry and bawle as if we were vnwilling to bee borne; and when we are a dying we are mad at that.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take hence that Wolfe that barkes thus.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I am muzzel'd, but one word with your Maiestie, I am sober sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You oft call Parliaments, and there enact
Lawes good and wholesome, such as who so breake
Are hung by th' purse or necke, but as the weake
And smaller flyes i'th Spiders web are tane
When great ones teare the web, and free remaine.
So may that morall tale of you be told,
Which once the Wolfe related: in the Fold
The Shepheards kill'd a sheepe and eate him there
The Wolfe lookt in, and seeing them at such cheere,
Alas (quoth he) should I touch the least part
Of what you teare, you would plucke our my hart,
Great men make Lawes, that whosoe're drawes blood
Shall dye, but if they murder flockes 'tis good:
Ile goe eate my Lambe at home sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Part, and thus reckon neuer to see her more.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Neuer!

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Neuer thus, but thus a Princes whore.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Thou dar'st not, if thou do'st; my heart is great,
Thus wrong'd, thou canst doe little if not threat.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: At what dost-laugh?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: At a thing of nothing, at thee; why shouldst thou be afraid to fall into the Cuckolds disease.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Because it makes a Doctor an Asse, nothing can cure it, are you answer'd Sir?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Come th'art a foole, to grieue that thy wife is taken away by the King to his priuate bed-chamber,
sp.l: Now like a booke call'd in, shee'l sell better then euer she did.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Right sir, but could he chuse no stocke to graft vpon, but that which was planted in my nurserie.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Ile shew thee a reason for that.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Leachers comming to women, are like Mice amongst many Cheeses, they taste euery one, but feed vpon the best: hornes rightly weigh'd are nothing.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: How nothing! oh sir, the smallest Letters hurt your eyes most, and the least head-ach which comes by a womans knocking hurts more then a cut to the scull by a mans knocking.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Yet I warrant thou dar'st sweare the party's honest?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ha; sweare; not I, no man durst euer sweare for his wife but Adam, nor any woman for her husband but Eue, fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Whether art flying?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: In peices dost not see I'me shot out of a Cannon.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Downewards Ile shoote thee, but as Diuels vse
Ile tickle at thy tortures, dance at thy stumbling,
Play with thee, and then paw thee, 'shalt make me merry
The Crowne of blacke deeds that are hatcht in Hell
Is to out-liue and laugh, and all's play'd well.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I haue not pass'd by a Don, to touch whose hand mine owne was neuer more troubled with a more terrible itch.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: I haue not met a Signior, at whom mine owne eyes (as if roasted enough) did euer burne more in desire to flye out: so that whether to recoyle or aduance on, I am betweene Hawke and Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: The honey of sweet Complement so turne vp your Tuskes or Mochatoes, that they be not too stiffe, to brisle against my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: Your acquaintance is a Limbeck, out of which runneth a perfum'd water, bathing my nosthrils in a strong scent of your embracings: are you of Court Signior?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.l: No Signior of the City: are you a Don of the Citie!

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: No Signior of the Court City, I smile,

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.l: Why.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: I assure you Signior, you are to vs of the Court but Animals You are held but as shooing hornes to wait on great Lords heeles.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Let em pay vs what they owe then, and pull on their shoes, and wee'll wait no more.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: You are our Apes.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.l: But you are fuller of Apish-trickes.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: No sooner leape our Ladies into a fashion, but your Wiues are ready to creepe into the same.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Why not; for tho some of your Ladies invent the fashion, some of our wiues husbands are neuer pay'd for the stuffe or making.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: Giue way with your poore scull to our oares: for I tell thee Signior you of the city, are the flatten milke of the kingdome, and wee of the Court, the Creame.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: I tell thee Signior! wee of the City eate none of your Court butter, but some of your munch vp our flatten milk cheese.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: Be not too loud; tho you are good ringers in the City, for most of you haue bels at your doores.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Be not you too loud: for you might be good singers at Court but that most of you are spoyled in learning your pricksong.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: Bee temporate: I will shew you your City Cinquipace, you beare, sweare, teare, reare, and weare; you beare the Tanckerd, sweare shop oathes, teare money out of debtors throates, reare rich estates, weare good clothes, but carry your Conscience in torne pockets.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Bee attentiue, I will shew you your Court Coranto pace, it consisteth of 5. bees and 3. cees; you borrow of any man, are braue on any termes, brag at any hand to pay, bellow at any that demands it, bite any Catchpole that fangs you, but carry neither Conscience nor coyne in your whole pockets.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p:
Tell mee Signior, tell mee why in the City does a
harmlesse signe hang at the doore of a subtill Nicodemus sitting in a shop?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: And tell me Signior, tell me, why when you eate our good cheare i'th City, haue you handsome wide chops, but meeting vs at Court, none; your gumme's glew'd vp, your lips coap'd like a Ferret, not so much as the corner of a Custard; if a cold cup, and a dry cheate loafe 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: Come, come, You are Acornes, and your Sonnes the Prodigals that eate you vp.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Goe, goe, you are Prodigals, and glad of the yellow Acornes we leaue our Sonnes.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: I will crosse my selfe when I owe money to a Citizen, and passe by his doore.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: I will blesse my selfe, when a Courtier owing me no money, comes neare my doore.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You are discended from the tanckerd generation.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: You are ascended vp to what you are, from the blacke Iacke and bumbard distillation.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: Deere Signior.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.l: Delicious Don.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Boy.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Art sure thou saw'st the Admirall at Court!

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Am I sure I see your Lordship in your gowne.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: And talking with the King?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Most familiarly.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: And what say the people about my committing to mine owne house?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: The beast grinnes at it, there's a Libell already of you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: A Libell, away.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yes faith my Lord, and a Song to the tune of Lament Ladies, Lament.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I'me glad the stinkards are so merry, a halter on 'em, it's musick to them to haue euery man thrown off, you haue seen the Kings Mistris, boy haue you not, what manner of peice is't?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Troth my Lord I know not, I neuer saw her shot off, a pretty little pocket dag.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: What report giues she?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: A very good report of her Husband, but he giues an ill report of her.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: How does the Ladies take it; now the King keepes a
Wench vnder the Queenes nose?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: They take it passing heauily, it goes to the heart of some of them, that he keepes not them too.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I heard say they were all once leauing the Court?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: True sir, but there was a deuise which stopp'd 'em.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Who are you!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My Lord, we must speake with you.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: What are you? fetch me a weapon

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Your friends.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Sdeath breake it open.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: The King; I did not vnderstand your Maiesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You shall, for Ile speake plaine to you, know you these?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You doe not, a Kings arme thou seest
Has a long reach, as farre as Portugall
Can We fetch treason backe hatcht here by you.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Me!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thee and the trayterous Portugals to depriue me
Of life and Crowne, but I shall strike their King
And them, and thee beneath into the earth.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: And lower then earth you cannot.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Halfe your body is in the graue, it only lackes our hand
To cast the dust vpon you, yet you stand
On slippery Ice your selfe, and trip at vs
Whose foot is fixt on Rocks, but since th'ast, throwne
Thy selfe downe neuer looke to rise.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I care not, I will be little so in debt to you, that I will not owe you so much as God a mercy for my life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You shall not then, stand not to ayme at markes
Now roue not but make choyse of one faire white
Th'ast but one arrow to shoote, and that's thy flight
The Admirall knowes our pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: And Heauen knowes mine
Left in mine enemies hand, are you my Iaylor?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No my Lord, I thinke I'me rather left
To be your Confessor.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I need not any,
That you and I should both meet at one Ball,
I being the stronger, yet you giue the fall.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A kind of foot-ball slight, my Lord, men vse
Exceeding much at Court, your selfe has heard
Little shrimps haue thrown men higher then the Guard;
But barring this rough play, let's now consider,
For what I stay, and what you are to doe.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Doe what?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: To die.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: And must you play the Hangman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Breake in fellowes.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: 'Sdeath what are these?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your Executioners appointed by the King.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: These my Executioners,
And you my ouer-seer; wherefore kneele they?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: To beg your pardon, for they feare their worke
Will neuer please you.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: What booke's that they hold
This is no time for Dedications.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That booke is sent in Loue to you from the King
It containes pictures of strange sundry deaths
He bids you choose the easiest.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Then I chuse this.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your choyce is ill made.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I'me more sorry Sir,
I had rather haue my body hackt with wounds,
Then t'haue a Hangman fillip me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My Lord pray pardon me
I'me forct to what I doe, 'tis the Kings pleasure
To haue you die in priuate.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Any where
Since I must downe, the King might let me fall
From lofty Pinacles, to make my way
Through an arm'd Feild, yet for all that, euen then
Vnlesse I slew a kingdome full of men
I should at last be pay'd home: blackest fate
Thy worst, I heere defie thee, what the State
Appoints 'tis welcome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That's to haue your head.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: 'Tis ready.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hee'l be quiet when you are dead.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Madam there's a fellow stayes without to speake with you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: With me!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Your shoo-maker I thinke.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Ha'st brought my shooes?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: You drew them not on last.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: No Madam, my Master that seru'd you last has very good custome, and deales with other Ladies as well as you, but I haue fitted you before now, I should know the length of your foote.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: I doe not remember thee.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I'me sorry you haue forgotten me.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: What shooe was the last you drew on?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: A yellow.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: A yellow! I neuer wore that cullor.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes Madam by that token when I fitted you first, you wore not your shoes so high i'th instep, but me thinks you now go cleane awry.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: A fault I cannot helpe, manie Ladies besides me goe so,
I hope 'twill grow to a fashion..

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Has not that fellow done there?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes sir, I haue now done, I haue a suit to you Madam, that none may be your shoo-marker but I.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Thy Master thou sayst serues me, I should wrong him then.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Yet doe you me more wrong, oh my Tormiella!
Is the leafe torne out where our Loue was writ,
That I am quite forgot!

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Softly good sweet.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Oh miserie, I make my selfe a theefe,
To steale mine owne, another at my fire
Sits whiles I shake with cold, I fatten a stranger,
And starue my selfe.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Danger throwes eyes vpon thee,
Thus visit me, watch time for my escape
To any Country, by thy dearest side
Ile lackey all the world or'e, Ile not change
Thee for a thousand Kings; there's gold.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Not yet done?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes sir, I'me onely taking instructions to make her a lower Chopeene, she finds fault that she's lifted too high.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The more foole shee.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: The King comes Madam, he enquires for you.
sp.stage: Enter King, Valasco, Gazetto, and others.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My brother Iohn is gone then?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I ha bestow'd him as you commanded, in's graue.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hee's best there,
Except the Gods, Kings loue none whom they feare.
How now!

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: My Shoo-maker.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh hast fitted her, so, hence sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: As a worme on my belly, what should the Ant,
On his poore Mole-hill braue the Elephant,
No, Signior no,
No braines to stay, but saues a head to goe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let me haue no more of this: haue not we eyes
Pointed like Sun-beames, goe to, get you in.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Angell from Heauen, falne a Kings Concubine.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: May it please your Grace,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Her Highnesse drown'd in sorrow, that your brow
Has beene so long contracted into frownes,
Wishing to die vnlesse she see it smooth'd,
Commends her best loue to you in this Iewell
The Image of her heart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Lord Admirall, my wife's growne kind, see!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: One of the happiest houres
Mine age e're numbred; would your Hignesse now
Would fetch vp the red blood her cheekes hath lost
By sending her, some simbole of your loue.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Pray step your selfe vnto her, say I locke
My heart vp in your bosome to her vse, and giue it her

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ile lend it in your name.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Doe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She shall pay her heart for it in interest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ile see her anon
Leaue vs, stay you, and set that Table here.
A chaire, none trouble vs, doe you serue the Queene?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We know you now, y'are in our eye
Are the doores fast?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They are Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nearer yet,
Doe not you know of a conspiracie,
To take away my life vpon Saint— tush,
No matter for the day, you know the plot Sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By Heauen I know of none!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Blushing doe you staine?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is not guilt but anger.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Y'aue all fixt
Your hands and Seales to an Indenture drawne
By such a day to kill me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For my part
My Loyaltie like a rough Diamond shines
The more 'tis cut, I haue no hand in that
Or any basenesse else against your Life
Or Kingdome.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fetch me Inke and Paper
I soone shall try that, come Sir write your name:
Stay, your owne words shall choake you, 'twas a letter
Wrap'd vp in hidden Characters, and sent
Inclos'd in a Pomgranet, to a great Don
And thus subscrib'd: At your pleasure your obsequious vassaile
Write this, and then your name, here.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: At your pleasure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy hand shakes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No sir, Your obsequious Vassaile.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here sir, your name now there so low it stood.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Martines Cazalla de Barameda.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: There's in thy face no Traytor I cannot tell
Good mouthes haue giuen thee to mee, on your life
Be not you like a Wolfes-skin Drum to fright
The whole Heard by your sound, I will compare
Your hand with this, that's all, but sir beware
You prate to none of what 'twixt vs is past.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Were I i'th world aboue, I would desire
To come from thence, to giue that man the lye,
That once should dare to blot my Loyalty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Here take this Key, meet mee some halfe houre hence i'th priuy Gallery with two naked Poniards.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Two ponyards.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yes, goe send some body in, stay, Lupo
Can you write?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Indite a Letter— 'sdeath sir— heere begin

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: After my heartie Commendations, so sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How! write— My most admired Mistris.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Mired Mistris,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: With the fire you first kindled in me, still I am burnt.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Still I am burnt:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: So that Thunder shall not hinder mee from climbing the highest step of the Ladder.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Climbing the highest step of the Ladder.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Of your perfections, though I bee confounded for euer.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Be confounded for euer.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your high pleasures are mine, mine yours.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Mine yours.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And I dye euer lastingly vntill I bee in your bosome.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: And I dye— vntill I be in your bosome.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where are the Gentlemen of our Chamber?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Without Sir?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Bid them attend vs close.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Would this dayes worke were done, I doe not like
To see a Bull to a wild Fig-tree ty'd
To make him tame, beasts licking 'gainst the hayre
Fore-shew some storme, and I fore-see some snare:
His sword is dipt in oyle, yet does it wound
Deadly, yet stand it, innocence wrong'd is crown'd.
sp.stage: Enter the King, Alphonso, and Gazetto.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Treason!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Kill the Villaine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stay, none touch him
On your liues; on Kings shoulders stand
The heads of the Colossie of the Goddes
(Aboue the reach of Traitors) were the beds
Of twenty thousand Snakes layd in this bosome,
There's thunder in our lookes to breake them all,
Leaue vs.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: You are too venturous.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ioue cannot fall,
Both person place and businesse were quite lost
Out of our memorie, lay aside these poniards
We haue alter'd now our businesse, you shall beare sir
Our salutation to the Queene— not seal'd!
'Sfoot, nor indors'd! some Inke, come let the forehead
Haue no more wrincles in't-but this, to the Queene,
Write it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To the Queene, no more!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No, no, 'tis well,
Hast thou no Seale about thee? if my wife
Exceptions take missing our royall signet
Say that not hauing that, I borrowed yours.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I shall Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hide it, goe-without there.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You met him did you not, how lookt the slaue?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Most strangely.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Vnparalel'd Villaine! Diuels could not set
To hatch such spitefull mischiefe, guard me closely,
When you see him at the stake then worry him,
Are all weapon'd?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: All, all.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: When Darts inuisible doe flye,
A slaue may kill a Lyon in the eye.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Who gaue you this?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: A Gentleman of your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Qn.
sp.l: Call in the Villaine,
Thou audatious Serpent!
How dar'st thou wind in knotted curles thy lust
About our honour; where hadst thou this Letter?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I had it from the King.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Out impudent Traytor.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now at Barle-brake, who are in Hell?
What's that? to the Queene, what Queene!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Me, 'tis to me
Your mistris there the Messenger, her Secretary
Hee heere.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Vds death.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Your Trull and hee haue laid
Traines to blow vp mine honour, I am betray'd.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lupo, Fasten her.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Fasten mee!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Iago see.
Looke all, bind fast this Diuell, is there no Circle
To be damn'd in but mine.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Slaue let me goe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh thou lustfull harlot.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Guard me Heauen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'me sold.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thou Villaine speake truth.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Keepe her off.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Most basely.
Betray'd and baffled, is that Letter the same
I sent in to the Queene.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is this thy hand?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis sir, but heare me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And this thy name, thy hand?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My name, my hand.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Saue him and let him spit
His blackest poyson forth?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Spare him, vnhand her.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Let me haue Iustice as thou art a King!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To prison with them both.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: As I am thy wife
Make not thy selfe a strompit of me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hence, guard her.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I come Heauen, guarded with innocence.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Follow your Mistris, you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Yes, to her graue.
Oh that I now were swallowed in some Waue.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh that I
Should in a womans lap my Kingdome lay,
Honour and life, and she should all betray
To a Groome, a slaue.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Let not her poyson run
Too neare your heart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Iago I haue done,
Pray let my greife want company, this wracke
So great, shall make th'whole Kingdome mourn in black.
Lupo!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Did your Highnesse call!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yes, harke thee Lupo:
It may bee th'art a Serpent dull of sight,
Be quicke of hearing, may be th'art a Hare
And canst see side-wayes, let me locke vp here,
What euer's layd in there.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I am strongly charm'd.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Wilt venter for me?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: To the threshold of hell.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: May I trust thee?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Else imploy me not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Didst euer kill a Scorpion?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Neuer, I ha beene stung by one.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Didst neuer bait a wild Bull?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: That's the pastime I most loue and follow.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A strange disease
Hangs on me, and our Doctors say the bloud
Onely of these two beasts must doe me good,
Dar'st thou attempt to kill them?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Were they Diuels
With heads of Iron, and Clawes ioynted with brasse,
Encounter them I shall, in what Parke run they?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Queene that Scorpion is, Tormiellas husband
The mad Oxe broken loose; in a small volume
What mischiefe may be writ, in a maze!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: No, in a muse,
I'me plotting how to doe't, and to come off.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This does it, by this key burst vp all doores
That can betray thee, done be sure to rise,
Let a Kings royall breath, send the hence flying.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: As Powder does the Bullet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Heap'd vp honours
Are scedules to thine enterprise annext,
Doe it and mount—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: To th'Gallowes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy selfe goes next.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I scorne to be thy bloud hound
Why should I vexe a Soule did neuer greeue me?
The Queene an honest Lady: should I kill her,
It were as if I pull'd a Temple downe,
And from the ruines of that built vp a stewes,
She liues, but Butcher like the Oxe Ile vse.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Oh royall Sir, my Daughter Tormiella
Has lost her vse of reason and runne mad.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: When!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Not halfe an houre since.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Mad now! now frantique!
When all my hopes are at their highest pitch
T'inioy her beauties! talke no more: thou ly'st.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: May it please your Maiestie-

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Curses consume thee— on—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: It is dispatch'd, the Queene is lost, neuer to be found.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Waue vpon Waue,
Hard hearted Furies, when will you dig my Graue:
You doe not heare him, thunder shakes Heauen first
Before dull Earth can feele it:
My deere, dearest Queene is dead.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: The Queene dead!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What said she last!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Commend me to the King
And tell him this, mine honour is not wrack'd,
Though his Loue bee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And so her heart-strings crackt!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Some tricke vpon my life, State-coniuring
To raise vp Diuels in Prisons, and i'th darke:
If she be dead, Ile see her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Villanous man,
Thou see what we haue inioy'd, thou impudent foole
Away, Iago giue this tumbling Whale
Empty barrels to play with, till this troublous Seas
(Which he more raging makes) good Heauen appease.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well, I say nothing, Birds in Cages mourne
At first, but at last sing; I will take my turne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Queene dead, I shall now haue riming slaues
Libell vpon vs, giuing her innocent wings
But say we murdered her, scandall dare strike Kings:
Then here's another Moone of Spaine Eclips'd,
One whom our best lou'd Queene put in her bosome,
For sweetnesse of pure life, integritie,
And (in Court beauties wondrous) honesty,
Shee's mad too, Lupo, Tormiella's mad!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Mad!

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: As a March whore.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Mad, shall I worke vpon her?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Vse thy skill.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I would to Heauen your highnesse—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha! the Queene! was she not at my elbow?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Here was nothing.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I must not liue thus, Iago if I lye
After the kingly fashion without a woman
I shall run mad at midnight; I will marry
The Lunaticke Lady, she shall be my Queene,
Proclaime her so.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Your highnesse does but jest!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: All the world's franticke, mad with mad are best.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Wretched state of Kings, that standing hye,
Their faults are markes, shot at by euery eye.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Giue me the key, make all fast, leaue vs, Ile skrew her wits to the right place.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Apollo blesse thee.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Are not you a woollen-Draper?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Whether is a womans life measured by the Ell or the Yard.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: All women by the Yard sure, it's no life else.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: I'me now neare seuenteene yeares old, if I should dye at these yeares, am I not a foole.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Yes marry are you, for the Law allowes none to be of discretion, till they come to twenty one.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Out vpon you, you are a Lawyer, pray get you hence, for you'l not leaue me clothes to my backe if I keepe you company, I'me mad enough now, and you'l make me starke mad.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I am not what I seeme, no Doctor I
But by your Husband sent in this disguise
To sound your bosome.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: You bob for Eeles, doe you not?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Here has he lockt his mind vp, but for mee
To put a burning linstocke in a hand
That may giue fire, and send my Soule in powder,
I know not, pardon me, fare you well Lady.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Hist doe you heare?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: The eyes of mercy guard thee
Were't knowne for what I venter'd thus, 'twere death,
Ile to your husband.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Stay, I am not mad
Yet I haue cause to raue, my wits like Bels
Are backward rung, onely to fright the Tyrant
That whilst his wild lust wanders, I may flye
To my sweet husbands armes, here I haue hid
The traines I meane to lay for mine escape.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Excellent, he shall second you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Should any watch vs!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: All's fast, run mad agen then, the King thinks
Me some rare fellow, you shall leaue the Court
Now if you'l taste my Counsell.

sp.speaker: Torm.
sp.l: Ile drinke gall to cure mee of this sicknesse.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Sit then downe here
Ile bind you fast because it shall appeare,
That you grow worse and worse, then will I tell
The King, the onely course to leaue you well,
Is to remoue you home to mine owne Lodging,
Ile bind you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: For euer to thee.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Once hence, you may flye
To th' Straights, and then crosse o're to Barbary:
So, th' art a Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: What's that you speake!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: A damn'd one;
Dost thou not know me! I am Gazetto!

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Mercy.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Who like a ball of wild-fire haue beene tost
To make others sport, but here I burst and kill:
A periur'd Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: I am none,
My Father swore that I should marry thee,
And then a Tyger and a Lambe had met,
I ne're was thine, nor euer will be.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Sweare thou art not mine,
That when I see thy heart drunke with hot oathes,
This Feind may pitch thee reeling into Hell,
Sweare that thou art not mine.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: By heauen I am not,
To proue I sweare right to thee, change that weapon,
See at my Girdle hang my wedding kniues,
With those dispatch mee.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: To th' heart?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Ayme right I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Ile not kill thee now for spight
Because thou begst it.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Then good villaine spare me!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Neither, heere's that shall sinke thee; to the King
Thy iugling and these Letters shall be showne.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Vpon thy head be my confusion
The King! I shall both feed his rage and lust,
First doome me to any Tortures!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Thou shalt then sweare—
Because I know he'll force the tye a knot,
The Church must see and sigh at, if he marries thee,
Sweare when he comes to touch thy naked side,
To bury him in those sheets, thou art his Bride.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: By Heauen that night's his last, my iust hart keepes
This vow grauen there.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Till then my vengeance sleepes,
Where is the King?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I haue refin'd
That Chaos which confounded her faire mind.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Moue in thy voice the Spheares, when next thou speakst, Tormiella.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: I am well my fearefull dreame
Is vanisht, thankes to Heauen and that good man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou giu'st me another Crowne, oh Vindicados,
The axletree on which my Kingdome moues,
Leanes on thy shoulders, I am all thine; Tormiella!
Bright Cynthia looke not pale, Endimions heere,
Hymen shall fetch a leape from Heauen t'alight
Full in thine armes, backe thou blacke ominous night.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Signior Lupo, why Don, not know me, I am the poore Shopkeeper, whose ware is taken vp by the King.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: You lye.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: True, as Iudges doe with their wiues, very seldome, I am Cordolente a poore Gudgin diuing thus vnder water, to see how Neptune and his Mermaides swim together, but dare not come neare him, for feare he sets Dogfish to deuoure me.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: An excellent maske against the marriage, now get a private Coat, the King meanes to haue you stab'd.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: He does that already, with the bodkin that sticks in my wifes hayre.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: He has not the patience to stay the dressing of his meat of thy prouiding, he will haue it taken vp, and eate the flesh raw, he will be married incontinently.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Will she set her hands to my hornes?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Yes, and set them to your head, she followes the steps of her old grandam, all euils take their names from her, the ills of Eue, thy wife for the hoope ring thou marriedst her withall, hath sworne to send thee a Deathes head.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Sworne!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Sworne, were thy case my case; I would set a Diuell at her elbow in the very Church, I would kill her as she gaue away her hand.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Wilt helpe me to a fit Circle to play the Diuell in?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Ile place thee, Ile put thy foot into the stirrup.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And I will rid the world of one of his diseases, a loose woman.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Farewell, eate her very hart. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: As we feed one vpon another, hungerly—
sp.stage: Hoboyes: Enter two Fryers setting out an Altar, Enter Iago, Alphonso, Gazetto, Malevento, two Churchmen, Tormiella next and the King, Ladies attending, Cordolente steales in, and stands in some by place, the King stayes or sits in a chayre, Tormiella is brought to him, as she is comming the King meets her; as the ring is putting on, Cordolente steps in rudely, breakes them off, Tormiella flyes to his bosome, the King offers to stab him, is held: she kneeles, sues, weepes, Cordolente is thrust out, Gazetto laughs at all, they are preparing to it againe, it Thunders and Lightens: all affrightedly— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p:
Dost thou tell me of thy Proclamations that I am banisht from the Court, that Court where I came to thee, was none of thine, it belongs to a King that keepes open Court, one
that neuer wrong'd a poore Begger, neuer tooke away any mans wife, vnlesse he sent his Purseuant death for her: oh thou daring Sacrilegious royall Theefe; wilt thou rob the Church too, as thou hast me! thrust me out of that house too in the Sanctuary, turn'd Diuell in a crowd of Angels!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Why didst not kill her?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I had no power to kill her
Charmes of Diuinity pull'd backe mine Arme,
She had Armor of proofe on, (reuerence of the place)
She is not married, is she, shorten my paines;

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Heauen came it selfe downe, and forbade the Banes.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: You must both to th' King.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Must! we are for him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Now doe I looke for a fig.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Chew none, feare nothing.
sp.stage: Flourish. Enter King, Tormiella, Valasco, Malevento, Alphonso.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Has heauen left chiding yet! there's in thy voice
A thunder that worse frights mee, didst thou sweare
In bed to kill me, had I married thee?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: It was my vow to doe so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And did that Villaine,
That Lupo Vindicado's, thrust this vengeance
Into thy desperate hand?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: That Villaine swore me
To speed you, I had dy'd else; me had he murdered,
When in a Doctors shape he came to cure
The madnesse which in me was counterfeit,
Onely to shun-your touches.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Strange preseruation!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Here comes the traytor!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Diuell, didst thou tempt this woman 'gainst my life?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Has she betray'd me, yes, hence Anticke vizors
Ile now appeare my selfe.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Gazetto!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I ha warm'd a Snake in my bosome.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: This is he,
To whom by promise of my mouth, (not hers)
Tormiella should ha' beene married, but flying him
To runne away with this, he in disguise
Has followed Both thus long to be reueng'd.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: And were not my hands ty'd by your preuention:
It should goe forward yet, my plot lay there
(King) to haue her kill thee; this Cuckold her,
Then had I made him Hawkes-meat.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Bloudy Varlet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Rare Prouidence, I thanke thee, what a heape
Of mischiefes haue I brought vpon my Kingdome,
By one base Act of lust, and my greatest horror
Is that for her I made away my Queene
By this destroyers hand, this crimson Hell-hound
That laughes at nothing but fresh Villanies.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: The laughing dayes I wisht for, are now come sir
I am glad that leaping into such a Gulph,
I am not drown'd, your Queene liues.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: She liues; I had no reason to kill her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A better Spirit
Stood at his elbow, then you planted there,
My poore Girle your sad Queene, breathes yet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Long may she,
Fetch her, commend me to her, cheere her (Father.)

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: With the best hart I haue.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let that slye Bawd
Engine of Hell, who wrought vpon thy Chastity
Be whipt through Sivill, foure such tempting witches
May vndoe a City come, you wronged paire
By a King that parted you, you new married are.
Inioy each other and prosper.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I doe already,
Feeling more ioyes then on my Wedding day,
I nere till now was married.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Nor I euer happy vntill this houre.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nor I, as I am true Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No sir, y'are no true Lord, you haue a title,
A face of honour, as in Courts many haue,
For base and seruile prostitutions,
And you are such a one, your Daughters fall
Was first step to your rising, and her rising
Againe to that sweet goodnesse she neuer went from,
Must be your fall, and strip you of all honours
Your Lordship is departed.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Does the Bell ring out! I care not
sp.p: Your Kingdome was a departing too, I had a place in Court for nothing, and if it be gon, I can loose nothing; I ha' beene like a Lord in a play, and that done, my part ends.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yes sir, I purge my Court of such Infection.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I shall find-company i'th City I warrant; I am not the first hath giuen vp my Cloake of honour.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh my abused heart, thy pardon, see
I haue sent home my stolne goods:

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Honestly!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: As she was euer; now with full cleere eyes
I see thy beauty, and strange Cheekes despise.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You call me from a graue of shame and sorrow.
In which I lay deepe buried.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: From a graue likewise
Your Maiestie calls me, I haue lookt backe
On all my poore Ambitions, and am sorry,
That I fell euer from so bright a Spheare,
As is the Loue of such a royall brother.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be as you speake, we are friends, it was our will
To let you know, we can, or saue, on kill.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Your mercy new transformes me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sirrah your sauing
My Queene, when I confesse (lust me so blinded)
I would haue gladly lost her; giues thee life.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: First I thanke Heauen, then him, and at last you.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: I had not the heart to hurt a woman, if I had, your little face had beene mall'd ere this, but my Anger's out, forgiue me.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Pray noble brother loue this man, he's honest,
I ha' made of him good proofe, we should haue had
A wedding, but Heauen frown'd at it, and I
Am glad 'tis crost, yet we'll both Feast and dance,
Our Fame hath all this while laine in a Trance:
Come Tormiella, well were that City blest,
That with but, Two such women should excell,
But there's so few good, th'ast no Paralell.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
